title: At Home Thyroid Test
content:
It’s believed by many doctors that our basal metabolic temperature or BMT is the most accurate measure of thyroid function.

We can check our own BMT at home by using an oral thermometer.  Not a digital one however.

This is how you do it:

  1. When you are ready to go to bed, shake an oral thermometer down and put it next to your bed where you can easily reach it in the morning. Don’t shake it down in the morning because this can raise your body temperature and the test won’t be accurate.
  2. When you wake up in the morning, put the thermometer in your armpit and leave it there for 10 minutes. Try and lie as still as you can.  Don’t get up or move as this too will increase your metabolic rate thus, raising your temperature.
  3. After the 10 minutes are up, record your temperature.
  4. Repeat this process for 3 – 5 days (at least 3 but preferably 5).

If your BMT consistently falls below 97.8 F, you may have an underactive thyroid.  BMT Normally ranges from 97.8 F to 98.2 F.

**If you have any kind of infection wait to take the test.

If you fall below and you have some of the symptoms below, it may be time to see your doctor for a blood test.

Symptoms of Hypothyroidism

Fatigue

Weakness

Weight gain or increased difficulty losing weight

Coarse, dry hair

Dry, rough pale skin

Hair loss

Cold intolerance (you can't tolerate cold temperatures like those around you)

 

MYAGINGANDWELLNESS.COM

Muscle cramps and frequent muscle aches

Constipation

Depression

Irritability

Memory loss

Abnormal menstrual cycles

Decreased libido

“Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the body lacks sufficient thyroid hormone. Since the main purpose of thyroid hormone is to "run the body's metabolism," it is understandable that people with this condition will have symptoms associated with a slow metabolism. The estimates vary, but approximately 10 million Americans have this common medical condition. In fact, as many as 10% of women may have some degree of thyroid hormone deficiency.   Hypothyroidism is more common than you would believe, and millions of people are currently hypothyroid and don't know it.”

title: READY FOR A CHANGE?
content:
READY FOR A CHANGE?

Change is a natural part of life and to resist it is futile. Changes occur all around us and there is nothing we can do about it. Sometimes change is good and sometimes, as we feel change, it may be uncomfortable, so we resist it.

Even after all the resisting we do, there comes a time when we are ready for a change. When we accept it, we listen to our inner self, possibly the one that has been talking to us our whole lives, but only now are we listening.

It’s the voice that we have always wanted to hear, but didn’t take its advice until now. It’s time for a change and with change comes healing and transformation.

Transformation is growth and with growth comes the ability to release the past, the pain, and accept what the future will bring. Many of us make New Year’s resolutions and most of us break them.I know I do within the first week, so I stopped making them. Do we really need the start of a new year to change something we don’t like? 

The key to making a change is wanting to do it. Even if we fail on our journey, the more we keep trying, the greater the chance is that we will succeed. I don’t need a diet to deprive myself. As soon as I say diet, I get a negative emotion that pulls me in the opposite direction and I automatically go right back to the way I was or sometimes worse.I get the opposite reaction.

Instead of feeling pleasure I feel pain, and this is what I focus on. I realize that I don’t need to constantly live like this. The fact is, I don’t need to diet; I just need to eat better. We as a society put so many restrictions on ourselves and when we don’t succeed we punish ourselves and the cycle continues.

I need to make a lifestyle change, that’s all. If you want to make a change, make a change, but don’t do it because of others. You know what will and will not make you a better person. This is the only change we really need to make.

There is no one solution for change. Everyone is different and it is through trial and error that we succeed. I tend to go in circles when I don’t know how to make a change. This wastes so much time that I often stop trying and start again later, only to go in circles again.

Once I fall, I know why I fell and I don’t fall that way again. Don’t get me wrong. I fall and sometimes many times, but eventually, I learn what doesn’t work even if only by default and I succeed in the end. It’s the only way I know how. No sense in kicking ourselves when we are down. It doesn’t make sense to be defeated before we start. I have wasted a lot of time in my life, not by trying and falling and trying again, nope, I have wasted more time not doing anything at all.

If you are sitting on the fence or the couch for that matter and you know it’s time for a change, what are you waiting for?

Momentum kicks in in any situation when we get started. Think about when you were in school and you had a term paper due. You may have been the kid who waited until the last minute because you didn’t have a topic and you didn’t know where to begin. Painfully, you waited until the last minute and got started the night before or the morning that it was due.

It’s not so much that time isn’t on your side, its momentum that kicks in and you get on a roll. Once you are at this phase, you are blowing and going and you see the end in sight. It’s just like change. You realize that it’s not so hard and wonder why you didn’t do it sooner. We make things harder than they need to be.

There are also elements of change. We need to understand there are several factors involved in changing.

Readiness, barriers and relapse should all be expected on the road to change. We only make change when we are ready to. I want my mom to stop smoking and take care of herself, but she is not ready to and at seventy-one, she probably never will be.

I can’t do anything about it, only accept it, and she has to own it and pay the consequences. I spent a lot of years trying to get her and others to change for the better and I always met with resistance. It wasn’t until I came to terms with the truth that no one will ever change unless they want to, not because I wanted them to.

Why I needed someone to be other than who they wanted to be, I don’t know. It’s obvious when health is an issue, you want your loved ones to be around; however, if this is not what they want, it’s no longer a problem for me. When I stopped preaching to my mother, our relationship got much better. She is happy with who she is, and if this is what she chooses for her time left on this earth then it is what it is.

Just like anything else, change comes if and only when we are ready and only then will it happen. When my mother passes one day, I will stand over her grave and think back to when I wanted her to change and then I will come back to the memory of her saying that she was happy with her life.

Barriers to change are other obstacles to overcome when we want to change. What is preventing us from changing? I will go back to my mother’s story (last time I promise). Why wouldn’t she want to stop smoking and get healthy so she can live longer and have a better quality of health? I would surmise that she doesn’t want to make the change because, in her mind, it would be more painful to live without cigarettes than it is to live with them.

They give her pleasure even if they are ruining her lungs. They are her companion when she is alone. Maybe she looks at the long term and feels the pain instead of making a specific goal of taking quitting one day at a time. It would be much easier to quit if she would think like this. Change is made when it is self-motivated and by positive thinking.

It’s important to know that change happens gradually. There will be relapse and there may be discomfort. Very few of us are so strong-willed that we won’t ever have a relapse. Like an alcoholic, not drinking is a lifelong change and one that must always be mindful of.

There will always be factors begging for our attention. Change means being proactive and, if you are, eventually, change will be a commitment you have with yourself.  Also know that you may resist what you must do but, you must do what you resist.

I wish you the best :)

title: LETTING GO OF EMOTIONAL PAIN
content:
LETTING GO OF EMOTIONAL PAIN

Sometimes our hearts are weak and our spirits are broken, but, still, we get up and go about the day and push down the pain. Maybe we were born with spiritual pain or we have unresolved issues that we haven’t let go of and we hold them inside not knowing how to let go. Some believe in past lives and that we are born with pain and this pain is punishment from a past life.

For those who are Christian, they don’t believe this, but believe that we can remove the pain by giving it to God. Give it to something or someone and let it go if you have it. It’s not worth holding on to. Without being mindful, we hold on to pain so tight that it leaves us exhausted.

Most of the pain is only in our minds and it is a dialogue we have with ourselves. I am not saying things didn’t happen to you in your past. Maybe you can’t even remember or pin point anything. I couldn’t imagine some of the circumstances people have gone through and are still able to live each day.

I have had hardships, but I am blessed that my pain is not as deep as other’s pain. All pain needs to be let go of, though. The point here is to give yourself the gift of seeking out help to rid yourself if you are in pain. Start fresh again, even if for only once in your life. Make the choice to be free.

We don’t understand how much we suffer and, conversely, we don’t know what it is like not to suffer. We expose ourselves to our pain by virtue of being in pain in the first place. We are constantly thinking about the pain of the past, the present and the pain we will endure in the future. We don’t know we are in pain most of the time, however, we feel it but don’t recognize it until we have a problem and it affects our behavior. We constantly talk inside our heads continuously doubting everything and this is causing us to suffer. Having to think about yourself all the time creates pain and suffering.

The reason we think about ourselves all the time is because we haven’t been okay for a long time. Listen to your pain; it’s telling you something, telling you that you must do something about it. The problem is we feel it but we don’t acknowledge it. Just like a broken leg tells you it’s broken, your spirit also tells you it’s broken too.

The pain that we carry around could be minimal or it could be monumental. I have heard that what doesn’t kill us, makes us stronger, and that suffering causes greatness. I don’t necessarily believe this as I believe it leaves pain wounds in our soul and, unless we intentionally choose to heal it, we have a problem.

Most of us think we are healing our pain by getting better at handling it. To solve your inner problems is to quit letting your mind mislead you. I don’t think time heals all wounds either. Time makes them a little easier to take, but we all know if we let ourselves go there, we can bring back the pain like it was day one. How we do this is by holding in that exact memory of when we first arrived at the pain. We can go back there again and again if we let ourselves.

When we think no one will love us and we are alone, or we will always be alone or there will never be someone for us, we are dealing with our minds inner dilemma. When we do find someone and the relationship doesn’t solve the issues that we have, we have an inner disturbance. We realize the void is still within us and then we move onto something else, because the pain is always there. But the real problem is we take our baggage wherever we go and we want to give it to someone else to carry, all the while picking up more as we go along.

Freeing ourselves from pain is a matter of unloading the memory and detaching the connection we have to it and then allowing it to diminish. It will take time and it will take a conscious effort to do it, but it can be done. If you have lost a loved one, you will have pain. In time it will get better. You will always have the good memories.

We have to address the source of our pain and not just cover it up or hide behind it. What if you did find a person or something that got rid of your pain? Have you really succeeded in solving the problem?

Nope, you just failed because you found something to delay or distract you, maybe a relationship in this case, in which you believe the other person will fix all your problems, or you’ll be okay as long as they are with you. Heck, you no longer believe you have any problems. You will see that you are still tormented as long as your inner stuff is not resolved.

The only way to resolve this inner conflict is to get out of it. Get out of your head and get out of your way. Let it go and remind yourself to listen to the addiction that your mind has created by staying in this place.

Stop and don’t get involved in your mind’s inner thoughts. Your mind is only playing games with you and you are going along with it. Be persistent in staying focused on not letting your mind tell you how bad things are.

You must stop it the second it starts talking. Don’t let a little reminder make a shift in your body telling your mind that you are about to go to the inner nagging again. Stop it before it starts. Be aware and don’t let your mind talk; only allow your mind to talk when you ask it a question and only ask when necessary.

The price of freedom from the pain is peace; therefore, we have to change. Change means we have to challenge what we know and what we are comfortable with. The key here is comfort. We are too comfortable with our disturbances, and thinking about change feels even more painful than staying where we are.

After all, we know the feeling and we are comfortable, even if it hurts. But, how do you know that change will be painful? What if it is a much better life and you don’t take the steps to get there because you are too afraid? How will you ever know about the life you could have if you don’t step over the line and try it? There are no boundaries that we must live in, just the ones we create.

Real growth means dealing with the discomfort, like it or not. Many times the actions we take are to avoid something. Stop avoiding and don’t let issues upset you. If you are avoiding pain and you encounter what you can’t avoid, then walk along side of it until it passes. And, if you do nothing else, don’t take things personally. Much of what goes on around you has absolutely nothing to do with you.

Take care of yourself :)

title: What are you meant to do?
content:
What are you meant to do?

What are you meant to do? What gifts do you possess that you have not yet discovered within yourself? That’s a rhetorical question because, if you knew what gift or gifts you had, then it would already be discovered, right? Well, not really.

You could be fantastic at many different things and you may not even realize it. These are the gifts that others see within you or that you are really good at. I cook a lot and I cook for a lot of people.

As a matter of fact, those who I cook for tell me I should open a restaurant, be a chef or a caterer. I was told this for many years, but I wasn’t hearing it. I just took their words with a grain of salt and thought they were only compliments I was being given as a token for making them food.

However, even though I was good at it, I believed it was just my hobby, and sometimes when you try and turn your hobby into a job, you don’t enjoy it anymore. I didn’t want a job; I wanted to continue having a hobby to relax and enjoy myself.

Sometimes we are born with certain talents. Well, not sometimes. I believe we all have at least one or two or even three, maybe more. Cooking is my natural gift, but writing is what I love to do. So there are two things I have to work with.

Surely either one of these will make me happy if I pursue them. What is your natural gift? If you don’t know, think about what others always tell you that you are good at. If you are passionate about something but feel you can’t do it for a living, then do it part-time. You must do what your soul calls you to do, otherwise, you are only working to pay bills and then die. On the other hand, if you like what you do and it’s paying your bills, then maybe this is what you are supposed to be doing and this conversation is moot.

There are more people working in fields that they don’t hold a degree in and, usually, it’s not by choice. We usually have to go where the money pays the bills and, before long, we are stuck in a job we don’t like or one that doesn’t challenge us.

I don’t know one person in my life who absolutely loves what they do for a living. They are okay with what they do, but they don’t love it. Maybe not all of us are lucky enough to love what we do, however, it’s worth it to try to do the work that we have a passion for.

Have you honestly taken the time to find out what you are made of, or do you know you should find out but continue to put it off? As the saying goes, “Someday I will get to it”, as in cleaning your closet or organizing your drawers.

Let me light a fire underneath you and remind you that someday will never come. What will come instead is “a road to nowhere.” Someday is when you wake up and you are literally too old to do what you should have done, only now you mourn the loss of what you can’t do anymore.

Yeah, I know, we are never too old to live our dream, but yes you are. If you want to live in Alaska for a year and live off the land, it gets pretty cold when you are in your late stages of life to do that. I can’t tell you how many times I hear, “If I were twenty years younger, I would . . .” I want to say, “Why didn’t you do it when you were twenty years younger?” I make it sound so easy, don’t I? Well, it is. If you take anything away from this, do now what you might put off later because we both know you probably won’t do it. Life gets in the way and then life flies by, and pretty soon we no longer have the opportunities we once had. What are you meant to do?

I hope you are lucky enough to find your passion :)

title: Food Allergy or Food Sensitivity?
content:
Food Allergy or Food Sensitivity?

 

"The lab results are back and you are allergic to everything you're eating!" This is what my doctor told me at a follow up visit.

Of course I was confused.  How could I be allergic to everything that I ate?  Wouldn't I be dead?  She handed me a report sort of like the book reports that we used to turn in, in high school.  You know the ones that have title, introduction, body and a conclusion.  All nicely three hold punched between a clear front and back cover.

I could see the title through the clear cover and it said.  "Food Allergy report for Theresa Skrobanek."

It was about ten pages long.  My doctor said that my allergies were more like a food sensitivity because I was eating the exact same things each day and/or, I had some other allergies so, I needed to eliminate all the foods in the report and then slowly work them back into my diet to see which ones I was allergic to and, which ones I had a food sensitivity to.

I was beside myself because that seemed like way too much effort and being a person who loves to eat, I was freaked out.  More so because, I'm already a Vegetarian and I was limited as it was to what I ate and now, I had to eliminate the rest of what I ate!!

Turns out that the problem was the frequency of what I ate.  On a typical day for about fifteen plus years, I would wake up, get a handful of almonds and shower.  Then, I would head out the door to work and at lunch I would head to Whole Foods and get tofu and salad.

For dinner, I would eat carbs, etc. and some kind of protein.  But I did this everyday of the week and soon it became a problem.  I didn't know it but my body was no longer absorbing any nutrients from the food  I was eating. It was now sensitive to what I ate.

We've all heard that too much of a good thing is not a good thing and who would have thought that those tasty little almonds would become my enemy all when I thought they were keeping me so healthy.

Some people do get sick from food allergies, etc. but, I just gained weight and lost nutrients.  My bones became brittle, I was anemic, my doctor added one supplement after another marking it up as just getting older until she decided to check me for food allergies.  It was as though I wasn't eating at all but just getting the calories stored on my body.

There are a lot of food allergies like gluten, dairy, yeast, sugar, wheat, corn, food additives, fermented products and even (dare I say it!) wine.  I love wine..  I won't make this a longer blog post than it needs to be because if you suspect you have a problem, it's wise to get a blood test.  It's quick and simple.  Just don't get carried away and walk around like I did and act like your allergic to everything a now you can't eat.

I eliminated the foods on the report and then worked them back into my diet.  Turns out that the change I needed was to not eat the same thing everyday and diversify my diet by, at least rotating food groups, like we all should do.

I do stay away from gluten and I have found out if you have an auto immune problem, like thyroid disorders (like I do), gluten can be like allergy and may attack the thyroid.  I don't want to take more medicine so it's very easy to avoid gluten.

Who knows, maybe I created the auto immune problem in the first place by eating the same exact thing everyday?

In the end, I am no longer anemic, my bones are stronger, I have lost ten pounds and I try to never eat the same foods two days in a row.  I haven't gone back to get retested.  I guess for now, I will listen to my body..

title: RESISTING WHAT MUST BE DONE
content:
RESISTING WHAT MUST BE DONE

I may need Alcoholics Anonymous (AA), but I won’t go. You may need to lose weight, but it’s too hard. My son may need to study harder to get good grades, but he won’t.

We all have things we should do, and maybe we really need to do them, but we won’t. We resist. Why do we resist? Because we think doing them will be painful.

My daughter told me that I hurt her feelings the other night, but I don’t remember. Now, it is very painful and breaks my heart to think that I have caused someone I love pain. But what will I do about it? Will I take a deep look at myself and ask the question, “Do I drink too much wine?” Or will I shove it under the rug blaming her as being too sensitive.

We all find ways to justify the things we do. It’s hard to step back and see ourselves the way others do. I’m not saying they are right, but if enough people are saying the same thing, then we should listen.

We all do things to defend the way we live. Let’s face it, if change were easy we would all change often. We make changing harder than it needs to be. Although, it can be difficult, because we can take one step forward and two steps back leaving us discouraged and then we give up.

If you take a few steps back, it’s not the end of the world. Change takes time and it’s not a straightforward event. Most of us don’t wake up and see that we need to make a life change, and then, on the first attempt, make the change without having any setbacks.

Think of those who have quit smoking. Yes, some quit cold turkey but most try several times before they finally quit. Those who attend AA have a sponsor to help them stay the course and, many times, for a lifetime. The truth is, those of us who falter don’t fall all the way down. When we try to change, we create stepping-stones that prepare us for the next step.

Do what must be done. Change starts with contemplation, preparation and action. You may be stuck in the contemplation mode for a very long time. This is the time when we are aware that we need to change and we comprehend that a change must be made in order to have a better life.

This is when we know there is a problem. Maybe your awareness is because of others pushing you toward a change. This time is also when we weigh whether or not the change is worth it. Some of us stay in the contemplation stage forever. We stay on the fence and don’t take the opportunity to better our lives.

We know we need to, but we are stuck in either fear or indecision. For some, it takes days or weeks to make a move and, for others, it is too painful to continue on their current path. The important thing is we are open to change as opposed to the reverse.

The next stage is the preparation phase. This is when we begin to plan for how we will make the change. We do the research and then take the first step. Someone who needs to lose weight may join a gym. Someone who needs to stop drinking may go to their first meeting. It’s also the time where outside forces begin to tug trying to pull us back into old habits. In order to be successful in making a change we must create strategies to maintain a different behavior. Temptation to go back to our old ways will be all around us.

The final (well nothing is final except death, right?) step will be to maintain your results. At this stage we create a time goal, for example, three months, six months, one year and so on. I know many people who quit smoking and were told the cravings would decrease after thirty days and the habit of wanting a cigarette in their hand would cease after ninety. T

hey were told that if they could get past these milestones, they were practically home free. Ex-smokers never forget their one-year mark from when they finally quit. Many still count the years since they had quit.

In the maintenance stage you should be out of the pain state and enjoying the new and improved you. The focus at this point is preventing yourself from ever returning to your old ways. Hopefully, at this stage you are stronger and more confident to maintain and sustain the new you.

Is there something that you need to do in order to be a better you? If something within your spirit is telling you that something is not right, trust your intuition because it’s probably right. It’s not talking to you for nothing.

Your inner self senses something is wrong way before you acknowledge it. I call this God speaking to you. I am not a religious person, but I am spiritual. We would all be a lot better off if we listen to our God-given gift of intuition. The same intuition that tells us not to go down that dark alley, and the same one that told us something we didn’t listen to it and we suffered the consequences.

Sometimes when this happens to me I ask God why he let this happen and I always get an inner voice that answers me, “I tried to warn you, but you wouldn’t listen.” Have you ever had this kind of experience? Listen to your inner self and it will always guide you in the right direction.

There is a difference between fear and intuition, and when you learn to trust your inner voice you will learn the difference.

title: Fear Is A Liar!
content:
Fear Is A Liar!

Wake up and feel the fear. Yep, exposure is how we get over fear, not by hiding from it.

We resist life because we have an underlying fear of not. Overcoming fear is a deliberate intention of taking action to take the necessary steps to do so.

In order to overcome fear, you must give up the struggle to remain afraid. We try too hard to protect ourselves and, thus, we don’t grow and we remain troubled.

Have you heard the phrase “You create what you fear”? It’s true. What you put out there comes back to you. If you fear you will always be broke, you will always be broke. If you fear you will always be alone, you will display this to others and you may even push others away.

The other side of this is to never make a decision based on fear because the opposite of what you intend will happen.

Some people build their whole life avoiding fear. They set their lives up so they don’t encounter anything that is troubling. We are not talking about the boogieman or a fear of spiders here, we are talking about the internal fear and the pain we hide inside.

It could be rejection or insecurity, whatever the pain is. We have to ask ourselves why we have fear and pain. By avoiding pain we end up bringing pain into every part of our life. Events affect our heart and simple things cause us pain, insecurity and an unfulfilled life.

It’s time to get some perspective and not let meaningless things control our lives. For me, I had the pain of social anxiety. It was very painful for me to go out in large social events. I didn’t realize this and I carried this pain for a long time. And what’s worse is that I manipulated the world around me to avoid the pain.

I wanted to be comfortable without anxiety, but I felt others were judging me when I was only judging myself. To be free, I began to realize that I was afraid of rejection. Wow! How ridiculous is that? First of all, people weren’t concerned about me at all. I only imagined they were.

Most people only care about themselves and they are not focusing on anything more than that. But what part of rejection was I really afraid of? Was I not good enough, pretty enough, smart enough? No one is perfect, right?

Eventually, I got over this by changing my thinking. I realized I didn’t feel good enough. This comes from childhood and issues about being moved from place to place and never being able to connect to long-term relationships.

Here is the kicker: we don’t have to be afraid. We can teach ourselves to unlearn most emotional pain and habits that keep us there. Nothing, or no one, came into my life and caused my anxiety; it was just my way of thinking that caused my pain. Nothing outside of me caused it and nothing outside of me could fix it. I was both the cause and the answer to my problem.

If for any reason you are living with some type of fear that is preventing you from living a full life, you can overcome it. Get some help, read self-help books, join groups, talk to someone. Make it your mission to remove this barrier while you still have time to create the life you deserve.

content:
ARE YOU ORDINARY NOT EXTRAORDINARY?

Are you an ordinary person who goes about your day doing plain and ordinary things when really inside you are extraordinary?

Are you a person hiding behind the effort to be the best you can be? Do you have this feeling, this innate knowing that you have a gift, a talent, an ability to be more than you are right now?

Have you always known there was something special about you, or that you could do something different or better than anyone else, but you don’t try?

We do mediocre work and we put in very little effort even when we know we are more capable and can do better. Maybe you are a genius, but you are fearful of exploiting it, or you can’t find the right opportunity to do so.

I know super smart people who don’t do anything more than what they have to do each day. They just exist. I wish I had one tenth of the intelligence I see go to waste.

Maybe you are a really good singer but you are afraid to get up and sing. You dream in your head about how awesome it would be to sing like no one was watching, and you fantasize about trying out for American Idol or something similar, even something smaller, but you just can’t do it.

Sure you could have stage freight and chalk it up to that, therefore, you feel better by justifying that it’s normal, so you will never live your dream. Instead of dreaming what you could be, take the steps to overcome the fear so you can be. I would bet that most singers had to overcome stage fright, too.

There are rarely any naturals out there as most have to practice doing what they love to do. I have a fear of speaking in front of a group. Many do, but I imagine that mine is extreme, but it’s not. If you search on Google for this, it is the number one fear, even more so than dying.

I can’t say I would rather die than speak because if God gave me only one choice, my fear would go right out the window to save my life. However, I don’t need to speak to groups because it’s not something I long to do, and not just because of the fear. I have no interest in speaking.

Although this could change as life does, this is something that will never be in my way. However, if you have a passion along with some talent and the only way to get you to your dream is having to expose yourself to your fear, then you better do it rather than live a life half full.

They say before you die you don’t regret what you did, but what you didn’t do. I love to write, not because I think I am a good writer, but because if I laid on my death bed and didn’t write than I would feel a sense of loss and disappointment.

Have you ever profoundly regretted something? Maybe you should have said sorry, but you didn’t and now it’s too late, or you left a great relationship only to find the grass wasn’t greener and now you live with regret?

If I listen to fear tell me I suck at writing (which it often does) and I don’t write, I am defeated and then I become ordinary, not extraordinary. Maybe I am not a great writer like Ernest Hemingway, but I am being extraordinary for trying because not many people write everyday.

What is it that you need to begin and then finish? Only ordinary people don’t reach beyond what they are capable of doing. Being extraordinary doesn’t equate to being what society might view as successful but, instead, it means what’s successful in your eyes.

I may feel extraordinary to myself and not to others, but isn’t that all that really matters anyway? In the end, aren’t we only in a race with ourselves? Which one are you, ordinary or extraordinary?
tag_names: ARE YOU ORDINARY NOT EXTRAORDINARY?how to be successfulhow to have a better lifehow to overcome fearsocial anxiety

title: Melatonin can stimulate your immune system
content:
Melatonin can stimulate your immune system

As we get older, our thymus gland, spleen and bone marrow (immune system) begins to go into atrophy (wasting away).  In medical studies, these functions can be recouped my taking the supplement, Melatonin.

Melatonin can recharge our immune system that's been undermined by age related declines.  We have receptor sites on the surface of our thymus gland, spleen and in our bone marrow cells.

If we add Melatonin to our supplement program, it appears that these cells can be revived!

Melatonin is also likely to protect our lymphocytes (white blood cells) against the effects of radiation. So in essence one might take a dose of Melatonin before going under any radiation treatment or X-rays.

Besides the benefits of helping us sleep as a supplement for insomnia, some are asking if Melatonin is a medical marvel or a medical myth?

Of course we need a lot more research for the use of Melatonin however, I would say that I take it every night for sleep and it lives up to my expectations.  If I get a recharged immune system as a side effect well, that's even better!

Did you know that Melatonin is a hormone?  Yep! I was surprised to learn that and then worried that I was taking a hormone and we all know what some hormones can do and that is to possibly raise our cancer risk.  However, studies have found that Melatonin is absolutely safe.

If you have a serious illness such as leukemia, lymphoma, an autoimmune disorder or major depression it will be wise for you to consult your doctor before taking Melatonin.  If you're pregnant don't take it either.

Melatonin provides anti-aging effects without poisoning any of our body's organs.  It actually fosters internal harmony.  There is no toxic risk, no dependency, or adverse effects.

I'll keep you updated on what else I find out about it.  Until then, you should probably consider Melatonin.

title: GOOD INTENTIONS
content:
GOOD INTENTIONS

Most of us have good intentions, but we let resistance get in the way. Good intentions mean that we want to do the stuff that needs to be done, but we also don’t want to disappoint others.

Often times, we will disappoint ourselves before we will others. Sometimes we intend to do what we need to do to get ahead in life, but our intentions are half-done because we may procrastinate or be unorganized.

We may set ourselves up for failure by creating lofty dreams that are beyond our reach. Some may say, "No dream is beyond our reach. We must reach for the sky and make it happen. We can become anything we dream of if we just do the work."

This may be true; however, if you want to be a singer so badly, but your voice is not good, then no matter how hard you try you most likely will not be a singer. Same goes for being a professional basketball player, football player, etc. First you have to have the foundation for what you want to become.

Sure, there are exceptions, but they are not usual and, of course, we can practice ten thousand hours, but if we can’t sing, jump or run, we are probably wasting our time.

We can still live in the music world by writing music, playing an instrument, teaching music or many others ways. Same is true with sports or anything else we have a passion for. Just because we can’t be the one thing we imagined doesn’t mean we shouldn’t modify our journey to get there.

The important thing is to see this and to acknowledge it and not to live in denial, because that only wastes time. Many of us fight tooth and nail and never make it to our goals, even with good intentions. Again, don’t waste time.

Be persistent in finding what it is that you excel at. Try several things and then narrow it down. In sales they used to say that you could not make a salesman, you are either born one or not. I think we can train people to become salespeople and I also agree that certain people are natural salespeople. They just have that ability and charm to sell anyone anything.

It doesn’t mean the person who was trained can’t make a good living in sales, it just means the person who has the innate ability may do better. In your life, do you want to work as a trained person trying to fit into a mold, or do you want to do something that you are naturally good at? Doing what you love is the reward this life can give you. Are you brave enough to find out what that is?

The other side of this is we may realize that we are not suitable for something, but continue to pursue it anyway. Or, something beyond our control gets in the way and our dream is no longer possible. Even with good intentions events beyond our control will happen.

This happened to a friend of mine. Her son always dreamed of being a pilot. He didn’t want to go into the military until he received his bachelor’s degree so he could go in with a higher rank. Life got in the way of his plans and, into his second year of college, he was diagnosed with bipolar disorder. When you have bipolar disorder and take medication, you can’t be a pilot and, unfortunately, bipolar disorder can be a lifetime diagnosis. So then what do you do?

Even though my friend’s son had intended to become a pilot, life got in the way and his plans were changed whether he liked it or not. That’s how it goes sometimes. Sometimes we are ahead and sometimes we are behind. The important thing is that which brings us down can also raise us up.

He had to reconcile himself to stop imagining flying a jet. The vision he had for many years was gone without ever being tried, and I understand this is unfortunate and probably hard to take. He had to see a new dream and he didn’t like this new vision at all. For a long time, he wouldn’t acknowledge that he could no longer become a pilot and said the doctors diagnosed him wrong, even going so far as stopping his medicine.

The bipolar symptoms would reappear and, eventually, he had to come to terms with taking the medication and not being a pilot. As sad as it is, life hits us like this and it’s just the way it is. The key is to be flexible in life. It’s the only way we can get through the times when life is beyond our control.

If we are rigid and we don’t want to accept certain circumstances, they will still happen whether we like them or not, and we will become stuck and left behind. The funny thing about life is no matter what happens in it, good or bad, it keeps moving even if we don’t.

Just because my friend’s son couldn’t be a pilot doesn’t mean he doesn’t have another calling. I won’t go into the “if one door is closed another one is opened” philosophy because this blog post is not a philosophy or psychology book and, really, that’s probably a little too cheesy.

I understand that some would probably be a little pissed off at themselves, the doctors, God, their DNA or whatever the reason because all they wanted was to have a dream, as they tell us to do, and pursue it, as they tell us to do, and become who we are meant to be, as they tell us to, and now fate steps in and screws it all up.

It’s hard not to blame something or someone for what life doesn’t give us. At this point, you have no other choice but to move on to the next person you were meant to be. Pitying yourself or not being anything that is good is not one of your choices either. Who knows, maybe the next person was who you were always supposed to be in the first place and divine intervention stepped in?

When life doesn’t work out the way we had planned, we must still have good intentions. The key is to move forward. Because you have to leave one dream behind doesn’t mean you can’t still create another one. You have to ask yourself the question again, “Who am I now and who do I want to be?” As we create a new dream, we may experience pain, anguish or sorrow for what we have lost, but we don’t need to suffer because we will always have choices.

You may not see where you need to go sometimes. Everyone goes through light and dark times and it’s a part of life. If we resist going through these times then this is when we begin to think like we are fighting a losing battle.

It’s only life getting the best of us in our minds. We will lose those we love, we will get sick, we will have things happen that are just ridiculously unfair. It happens to everyone and no one will escape the process as long as they are alive. But as the saying goes, “This too shall pass,” and hard times do pass, especially when we make the decision to move beyond them and accept them.

Let’s be real, if you could take away someone’s illness or tragedy, I know in a minute you would. Most compassionate people would. Events will be thrust upon us and it will hurt like hell. But you don’t have to live in hell. You have to realize it’s something you have to go through, and one day it will all be over and you will make it to the other side again and life will begin its cycle once more.

I wish you peace and happiness always :)

title: Being unorganized effects your health!
content:
Being unorganized effects your health!

In addition to resistant thinking and procrastinating, disorganization in life is a close third.

How many times have you looked for your keys, your phone, that paper you left on the counter and now it’s gone? You know that paper that’s important now, but wasn’t when you placed it on the counter, and now you can’t find it.

That paper that, if you don’t find soon, you are screwed. The one you blame everyone else for moving to another place or throwing away. In your mind you laid it “right there” and now it is gone. Maybe it’s your Jury duty summons and you forgot what day it was, only to realize it was today or approaching very soon.

Now you are in trouble. Maybe it’s your instructions, passport, a renewal form, a policy, homework, a check, your wallet, whatever. Every day some of us choose to misplace something or we can’t find what we are looking for and we waste precious time searching for it. Unlike anything else in life, we will never get back lost time and it seems like such a waste of life to be always looking for what you have lost.

The only way to overcome this is to get organized. Not being unorganized is another form of resistance and procrastination. Yes, another habit one chooses to do. This post is not about ways that I can get you organized, because it’s not really about a plan at this point.

Sure I can help you organize your drawers by giving you ways to label everything, or I can help you organize your closet by giving you examples of ways to organize your closet, but, again, it’s not really about that. Even if I did, would you do it? Being unorganized in life is a lot different and here is why.

Having a life that is organized has it benefits. Being organized saves us time, stress and money. If you live a stressful life because you can never find anything, than you probably know how it feels to be organized at least once in your life.

It’s a great feeling to look around and see everything in its place and to know what is in place. To have the ability at a moment’s notice to request something from yourself and then go straight to it is a great experience.

I have searched with others for hours looking for something, a wallet for example, only to chalk it up as being lost. Afterwards, the person who lost it went and cancelled their credit cards, got a new license and bought a new wallet. We found this wallet stashed in dirty clothes about three weeks later. What a waste of precious time and money to go through all that and, you know, it will more than likely be lost again until this person sets her mind to being organized.

Why should you be organized? Because for one thing, not being so can have health consequences such as being stressed, and we all know that stress causes high blood pressure, heart attacks and tons of other stuff I could name, but I know you get the point.

Being unorganized not only affects your health in a detrimental way, it also affects your productivity so much that you may be working at a low paying job or losing money because of it. By being organized you are efficient, which means that you are reliable, valuable and indispensable. If you are this way, it is likely that you will make more money, you will get promoted and you might never get fired.

If you feel that you are not always organized, but organized enough because maybe you show up at your job on time and in uniform, just so you know, it takes way more than that. By being haphazardly organized, you are not getting the true benefit of your job, meaning others see what you don’t think they do.

You will also realize they do because you rarely get a raise and you probably don’t get promoted. Many who are not organized are glad they have a job, but wonder why they are not further along in life. Maybe you think that your organization skills have nothing to do with your job because you work at a dead-end job and making extra effort won’t get you anywhere or any more money.

But an organized person gathers the information to create options to do better rather than staying in a dead-end job. They take the initiative and the necessary steps according to how they set up their own system to move ahead. An unorganized person has no system at all. Better yet, they say they will get to it later or they will start looking soon. Before they know it, years and people have passed them by, while they blame everyone else for where they are.

To break the cycle, determine why you are unorganized and then begin to unclutter your life. If you honestly don’t have time for anything, then it’s time to make time and start eliminating some of the events in your life.

If you work two jobs, work one better. If you run all over the place dropping off kids after work, try partnering with others to help or eliminate events. Decide to change. Determine what area of your life needs to change. Often times all we need to do is make a small change and everything else falls into place.

Using a calendar helps tremendously. We have smart phones now and they all have calendars that can remind us of when and where we need to be. Try to fill in the calendar for as far out as you can: days, weeks, even months. Every time a new event or appointment occurs, be diligent in putting it in your calendar. Anything that you need to do that can’t be put on the calendar, create the list I referred to before. Again, smart phones have lists apps too.

Don’t avoid doing any of these things the moment they need to be done and when that calendar reminds you, do what you need to. Work on your list until you complete it, and then once you get in the habit, you will create a mental list and the list becomes minimal. No more long lists because you are staying on top of your game. Don’t get overwhelmed by doing too much in the beginning. This is the only time you should spread out all the things you need to initially get done. Delegate the tasks that you don’t want to do to others and, most important, don’t always be a yes person and agree to things you know you won’t be able to do.

Do the best you can. On any given day, your best will change. One day you will be tired so your best may be the best for that day. On another day you will have an abundance of energy, use this time wisely. Just do your best and you will never have to second guess yourself or fall back to your old ways.

title: Eat right or die young!
content:
Eat right or die young!

The fats in our diets are usually the least likely to help our heath.  In fact, most are carcinogenic! Yep! Cancer helpers.

So if you don't want to invite cancer into your life then start by eliminating these types of bad foods!

  • Burnt foods, BBQ'd, smoked, fried
  • High fat cheese, butter, salad dressing and high fat oils

Instead, eat whole grains, legumes, fresh organic veggies, and fresh low glycemic fruits.

Let me tell why you should avoid the above mention bad foods.

*The best and smartest thing we can do is to avoid high fat intake.  This in itself will help fight cancer and keep us healthy and looking young.

Frying foods creates as toxic mix.  In addition to cooking your meal, by frying your foods, you are cooking up a toxic cascade of carcinogens. It's very wise to eliminate all fried foods.

Meat is another food you might want to avoid because meats are high in fat.  In fact, women who eat meat daily have four times the breast cancer rate of women who eat meat less than once or so per week.

I know, if you love meat this is a hard one to do however, maybe you can eliminate it once or twice a week.

Dairy foods are made from animals and they are loaded with fat, pesticides, hormones and other toxins.  Don't get fooled by butter substitutes either because they have large amounts of ugly fats called trans-fats.

If you like eggs, try and have one egg yolk per two egg whites.  The yolks have a lot of cholesterol.

Use oils sparingly.  Some are better than others like olive oil, etc. but they pack a lot of calories and more fat than you need.

Salad dressings are the foods that we don't realize that we eat way too much of.  Standard and even the lite versions are usually high in fat.

Make your own dressing by using balsamic vinegar, lemons/limes, herbs, etc.  Make it ahead and put it in a glass container to have a hand so you won't reach for the fat dressings.  Add soy yogurt to make it creamy.

Even though there are what is called "good fats" like in avocados and peanut butter etc. remember that a tablespoon of peanut butter is usually about 100 calories, which 90 calories of that is fat.  You should only have 10% fat in your diet so with two tablespoons of peanut butter, you've had your fat for the day.  Eat your fat wisely so you can enjoy it.

Note: If you eat peanut butter make sure its organic and certified Alfatoxin free as Alflatoxin is a mold-borne carcinogen common in peanuts.  Make sure you drain the oil after opening.

Lastly I will talk about snacks.  Just try and eat God made and not man made :)

Here's to your health, aging well and living for a very long time. Disease free :)

title: You want to fight cancer? Use your fork!
content:
You want to fight cancer? Use your fork!

It's no surprise that anti-aging and diet are inter-dependent.  Some foods promote cancer while others prevent it.  By eating the right foods and taking the right supplements we can dramatically reduce our overall risk of cancer.

There are thousands of molecules in foods.  Certain ones help us fight cancer.  These are essential nutrients and phyto-chemicals. These are anti-cancer compounds that interrupt the cancer formation process.

For example, foods/supplements with vitamin C stop nitrates from becoming carcinogenic.  Then there are the blocking agents of minerals that activate enzymes that chew up and remove cancer causers by breaking them up into little harmless waste products.

There are suppressing agents that block the progression of cancer once its begun.  These agents can be found it beta-carotene, selenium, calcium, flavonoids, plants. and DHEA.

Certain nutrients may have the ability to block metastasis promotion, detoxify carcinogenic molecules, encourage DNA repair, inhibit tumor growth factors, interfere with the binding of cancer cells, nourish the immune system, strengthen our natural barriers to carcinogens and much more.

You've heard the quote by Hippocrates "Let food be thy medicine and medicine be thy food." It's true.  If you want to live disease free or at least much healthier while you are on this planet, eat like your life depends on it!  You won't believe how good you will feel.

I have been a vegetarian for about 22 years.  I started eating cheese and dairy about five years ago.  In the last year or so, I have felt arthritis in my fingers and it got so painful that I was having trouble putting my shoes on.  I actually yelled out in pain last week.  That's when I knew something wasn't right.

When your body is telling you something, its manifesting itself from inflammation/disease and the result is pain and symptoms.

After doing research, I found that dairy is very acidic and acid causes inflammation in the body.  What also causes arthritis? Inflammation.  So naturally, if I ad more acid it will cause more inflammation and the cycle get's worse.

I have three choices at this point.  I live with the pain (because I hate medicine), I get a prescription or, I do what is the natural thing to do and that is, to listen to my body and get off of dairy. No brainer!

Too many times we get symptoms and rather than find out what the source of the problem is, we cover it up by thinking it's just old age or genetics or whatever we are doomed to have.

But really, is it that or instead our inability to make necessary changes to our diet. For example most type 2 diabetes can be reversed by eating better and exercising.  We can avoid certain cancer just by elimination with things like carcinogens.  We could also improve the chances of keeping cancer at bay if we ate 90% plant based diets.

I stopped the dairy and it's been about a week and I swear, I feel 90% less joint pain.  I've went back and forth testing my theory about dairy and each time I come back to being pain free.  I'm at the point to where even my great love of cheese pizza or cheese and wine doesn't sound better than being pain free.

Like they say, we will do more to avoid pain than to gain pleasure, I'm just glad I finally made that switch.

The take away here is two things.  One, do you have pain,  chronic disease or, an illness that you can try to "Let food be thy medicine and medicine be thy food?" and two, if you don't could you start to eat like you might avoid them in the first place?

title: PROCRASTINATION
content:
PROCRASTINATION

It’s kind of almost the New Year so I told my son he should make a New Year’s resolution to stop procrastinating. He looked at me, but said nothing and continued to postpone even the thought of it.

My son is a young man who makes his life a lot more difficult than it has to be by procrastinating. No matter what it is in his life, a speeding ticket, homework, an appointment, whatever, he will wait until the very last minute to do what he needs to do to get where he needs to be.

He does no research, no prep work and wonders why his life is always chasing him. His life is always in chaos as he lives through the consequences of procrastinating, both internal, by feeling and being anxious, and external, by having to turn in sub-par homework, forgetting about the speeding ticket and having to spend twice as much time showing up for court. And, let’s not forget the financial circumstances that come along with procrastinating.

The worse thing is he doesn’t see it. He doesn’t believe he procrastinates, but blames everyone and everything around him. I see it, others see it, but he does not, and no matter how much I gently try to show him his ways and explain that his life can be much easier, he only sees and believes what he wants to.

It’s disheartening, especially for a mother, to watch someone we care about go through pain and know there is nothing we can do about it, even when we know there is a solution. Like anything else though, he will have to experience the pain before he can see the light. I just hope it doesn’t take a lifetime.

The one thing he does have is a beautiful spirit, and I hope he doesn’t take too long so that his beauty can shine through. If he takes too long procrastinating, he will always be distracted and others will never be able to see the real man inside. I have seen, too many times, those who needlessly suffer by their own doing when a shift in thinking is all they need.

Think of all the money and time it costs us when we procrastinate. I have already stated what my son does, and he lives at home. I wonder how he will be able to survive on his own. If he doesn’t decide to change his habit of postponing and delaying his life, he may endure a life of financial disaster, among other things.

It is not unusual for a procrastinator to delay paying their bills and incurring late charges. It is not likely he will save money because he will probably justify in his mind that “he will do it later.”

There are many more examples of what one can do to create a damaging financial future, because we may be a financial procrastinator and we have definite mental hurdles to overcome. We may postpone our taxes, even if we’re due a refund. We may lose discounts because we didn’t pay on time. When you think about it, just the financial part alone is enough to make one stop being reactive and start being proactive.

Procrastination has its emotional effects, too. We can feel so overwhelmed and over-burdened by waiting until the last minute that we do nothing at all. Even depression is linked to being a procrastinator.

If you feel you are hopeless, you are not. No one is beyond the ability to stop. It doesn’t mean that you were born lazy, unless you want to be, or that you can’t be an efficient person. Procrastination is just a habit. Hear me here: it’s JUST A HABIT and nothing more. It is up to you to make the choice to change.

We are not born with a condition called “procrastination,” we merely create a habit. We choose to procrastinate because that’s what we do and we get used to it. There are no drugs that will keep us from doing it; it’s just us who must become aware of what we are doing and break the habit.

We don’t need to make more of procrastination than what it is and, again, it is only a habit that we choose. We can all overcome procrastination. How do we do this? We look for the reason why we procrastinate in the first place so we can create a strategy to turn our life around. It’s as simple as viewing the things we need to do as painful, rather than enjoyment.

­­­Everyday, people quit all kinds of habits, like nail biting, smoking cigarettes, over eating and so many more. You may say these actions are addictions, and I would agree, but they all started with an initial habit.

The good news is procrastinating is not an addiction. I am not a doctor, but I would bet that you don’t need therapy for it unless you are also clinically depressed, and that may mean you procrastinate because you have lost the drive to do more than what is necessary. Even so, this can be treated too.

Just so you know, there is no quick fix for procrastination. Like any other habit, we will not wake up one morning and say, “Today I will never procrastinate again.” Because, even though we may say it and we may sincerely mean it, we are creatures of habit and we usually go back to who we are.

It is true that very few people change (remember the resistant thinking I wrote about in an earlier post?), however, people can and do change if and when they really want to.

If they really want to are the key words here. Just like anything we need to do, we have to want to do it and, until then, like my son, nothing will ever change on its own. Life will keep moving, but your life will never transform until you do.

title: A way to easily lose a few pounds!
content:
A way to easily lose a few pounds!

A way to easily lose a few pounds. I gained ten pounds, two pounds at a time so I really didn’t notice it until I started feeling miserable.

Now, ten pounds isn’t really that much however, if we gain that much each decade, which doctors say it’s a very high percentage of that do as we grow older, than eventually, it’s going to catch up to us and manifest itself through obesity, a shift in our bodies ability to maintain the shape that we once had and, through diseases such as diabetes, cancer, heart disease etc.

A few modifications are all that is needed to get slimmer and stay that way.  It takes 3500 calories to add a pound to our body.  As we get older we tend to eat a little more fat and carbohydrates than we used to.  With that we add way more calories without even noticing that we added one-hundred, two-hundred or more calories in just one sitting.

I won’t even go into the mindless eating that we don’t even think about like grazing in the pantry, licking the spoons as we cook, trying samples of other peoples food, etc.  So if we added one-hundred little calories a day without even thinking about it, then it would be as follows:

  • 100 Calories per day X 365 days per year
  • 365 X 100 = 36,500/3500 per pound and viola we have gained ten pounds!
  • Now if we multiply that by each decade that we live 10 x ? (however long we will allow this to happen) .. You get the point.

So if you want to be slimmer or maintain your weight as you age then you might want to do the following simple steps:

  • Reduce your food intake by one-hundred calories (preferably two-hundred) per day.
  • Reduce your total calories if you are a woman to 1200. This takes the ability to count calories for about a month until you are a pro and then you won’t have to think twice about it.
  • If you drink wine, alcohol, etc. cut it in half. Sodas, eliminate them and drink unsweet tea sweetened with Stevia (a natural sweetner which tastes fantasti­­c) or lot's of water with lemon.
  • If you go over then subtract from the next day.
  • Drink a large glass of warm water with lemon or lime before eating and during a meal.
  • Eat a ton of vegetables rather than fruits and refined foods and eat lean protein.
  • If you go over then walk for thirty minutes in ten minute intervals if you hate working out. Every one can walk for ten minutes. If you are disabled then you will have to reduce your calories by at least a hundred or so more.
  • When you eat out, ask the waiter to box half of the food to go or ask for a box and do it yourself before you eat. You’ll have your next meal and only half the calories.
  • Consume more low calories soups and drink/eat them throughout the day.
  • Whenever I’m hungry, I tend to want to eat everything in site but I have found that, when I drink a cup of warm broth several times a day, it settles my stomach and makes me less hungry thus, reducing my desire to binge or over eat. I think it’s the warmth that makes the difference.

With these little food hacks, you will lose weight however, it will take some time.  But giving up a hundred or two calories a day isn’t all that bad.  It’s definitely better then those fad diets of fasting, no carbs, or juicing all day, etc.

Remember this will take some time but once you do this, you will see weight loss over time but this is A way to easily lose a few pounds!

If you really want to speed it up, add some workouts too!

title: DO YOU RESIST YOURSELF?
content:
DO YOU RESIST YOURSELF?

Are there things that you wish you would do, wished you would have done or, because time is quickly running out, you will never do? Do you distract yourself with phone calls, the Internet, friends and chaos, anything that keeps you from doing what you were meant to be doing? You were meant to be doing meaning, doing what God put you on this earth to do and doing what your spirit drives you to do.

Maybe you don’t think you know what that is. Everyone has at least a few things they are good at and even some things that they excel at, at least one of them. The problem is we resist what we need to do to find out who we were meant to be. Do you resist who you were meant to be?

You are probably wondering what the heck I am talking about and maybe thinking, Where is the writer going with this? Or saying to yourself, I don't resist anything, but I live each day and do what I need to do. What exactly is resistance? Did you know that doctors estimate that eighty percent of their patients come in with non-health-related issues? We are not sick, but dramatic!

Yes I said it. We are dramatic and doctors have to treat our drama like we have a medical condition, even when they can see that we may not. Even when we too know that we do not. We need attention, and with this attention we avoid what is happening in our lives. We go outside of ourselves for justification to keep resisting who we are.

We want validation for why we resist in the first place and that’s why we look outside of ourselves. If we are preoccupied, then we can continue to resist what we must do. Resistance can mean something as small as staying in the bathtub for too long when you know you should be getting ready to leave to try to be more productive at work. Or, it can be as big as putting off larger responsibilities that never get done. There is a price, whether big or small, when resisting life.

Some of us go from this condition to that condition; one gets cured and another one occurs. This is how we resist. We have one crisis after another and another but the drama, or the condition we have, is still resistance, which keeps repeating itself. If we don’t get out of our own way, we will get stuck. And the reason we get stuck is because we resist the art of who we are meant to be. Art is what we are put on this earth for.

I am not talking about the kind of art as in painting or sculpting. This art is the gift of creation that we all possess. It’s different for everyone, but we all have it inside. By resisting, we avoid our true self and we cultivate and create conditions or situations so that we keep going in circles. That’s why many of us get nowhere . . . well, at least where we imagine ourselves to be. Not to say having a successful life of some sort is a bad thing. The difference is having the courage and the commitment to completely have the life you dream of.

When we resist who we are meant to be, we manipulate the world around us. We live in the victim mode, which is the antithesis of doing the work necessary to become who we are meant to be. If you are living like this, stop and take a good look at yourself, and if there is something you have always wanted to do or someone you have always wanted to be, stop resisting it and give in and do the work necessary to get there. You will find it is much easier to stop resisting than it is to take the steps to get there.

We have all heard that it takes more work to pretend to work than it does to actually do the work. I have always believed that most of us wouldn’t resist if we knew what steps to take in the first place. I also believe that if we did know, many of us would have already created a better life.

There is no formula for it either, only action. Sure, there are those who are born with a gift and they are on a journey from the time they are born. But for most of us, it’s a journey of discovery. That’s the key, it’s a journey of discovery. It takes one step at a time.

It doesn’t have to be difficult, but because we think it will be we allow resistance to kick in and we throw in the towel, and then only dream of who we could be. Worse, we burden others with our stories of what we would have done or will do someday. No one wants to hear a story other than his or her own. The best way to show others our stories is to talk the talk and walk the walk.

steps you can feel amazing without depriving your self!  Click the link below:
