title: How to change your look as you age
content:
How to change your look as you age

 

I love to change my makeup, but I am guilty of wearing the same pink lipstick. A habit my husband says he wishes I would change, because he hates lipstick, especially when he ends up wearing mine. I decided to go to a nude lipstick, and it seems to serve me better (okay, with the color hair I have this month).

If you don’t change your appearance at least once a year, then you may be guilty of living in a comfort zone, and this is what I am talking about. Is it serving you well? Many times when we don’t make necessary changes to our appearance for fear of looking older, we can look older by dating ourselves.

I’m not talking about coloring your hair purple or pink (or blue for that matter), and wearing bright makeup with a mini skirt and stripper heels, gosh no! In fact, that will only make you look older, and let other people know there is something not natural about you.

Look at celebrities our age; the underlying theme is neutral with a little splash of color. This could mean you have blonde hair and neutral makeup, with a cute, colorful outfit or some trendy shoes. Or, you could add a pop of shadow with a neutral outfit, and add some color with your bag and shoes.

Updating your look shouldn’t cause you stress, nor should it be expensive. It’s a matter of keeping yourself modern. You update your phone, your computer, software, cars, etc. Don’t make yourself less important than the things and events in your life. You are much more important than anything else.

Surprise your partner; believe me, they will love the change even if they don’t admit it. Don’t be too predictable. Don’t grow your hair long only to clip it on the top of your head every day. What’s the point in that? Go for a style, instead of length. It will show off your best features.

And one last thing, clean out your closet! Believe me, if you haven’t worn a piece of clothing in six months, you probably never will. Let go of the past and welcome a new a vibrant future.

Many of us don’t realize that we are making mistakes with the way we wear our hair, makeup, and clothing. We can no longer shop the twenty dollar racks and pick out things that aren’t flattering like we did when we were young.

Yeah I know, we could make a sack look good back then, we could make anything work. Now it’s an investment we must make in our appearance that makes the difference. Yes, it’s an investment like your home and your car. Don’t you think you should at least come in third to those things, if not first?

Just because we should dress age-appropriate doesn’t mean we should dress in an unflattering way; very much the opposite. We can dress to complement our age and look great and even a bit edgy. The goal is to look as good as you can and be comfortable, but not try to re-create your twenties.

We can never go back, so why stress trying to. Be the best for the age that you are now. It’s very refreshing to see a woman own her age and still look great. It’s a glow that comes from within, chose to shine. Many women are afraid to make changes because they feel they will look silly. This is not true. We look ridiculous when we look the same as we did when we were younger.

title: Breast implant disease
content:
Breast implant disease.  Have you ever heard of it?  I just read an interesting article in an alternative health book.  I thought is was worth sharing if you have breast implants or are thinking of getting them.

The article says that regardless of the type of implant that a person has (saline, silicone, etc.) most women will probably develop health problems because the bodies white blood cells breakdown the implant coating.

The body literally chews off little pieces of the silicone casing and then carry the pieces into another area of tissue where where the white blood cells dies but, not before releasing foreign material in the tissue.

The point of the article is that ALL implants release foreign material no matter what type of implant there is and even, when they are not ruptured.

Get this, Dr. W. Lee says that it is estimated that  the release is up to five grams per year!! Scary..

Here is why implants may hurt us.

"Silicone is a sensitizing agent, which means it initiates an autoimmune or hyper-immune process." Which causes our own white blood cells to attack our bodies which can manifest itself as an autoimmune disorder like chronic fatigue, MS, or lupus.

It can also cause memory loss, poor concentration, arthritic pain, and other disorders.

Something worth thinking about before getting breast implants or maybe getting "un-implanted" if you have them and you have symptoms.

title: Do you change the way you look as you age?
content:
Do you change the way you look as you age?

Older women are the most dangerous on the planet. We have nothing to lose!

~Jane Fonda

Are we happy in the circumstances we are in, or have we settled as we have gotten older? Let’s face it; aging requires change. We can’t wear those sexy clothes we once wore, or wear the same makeup as when we were sixteen because that would be ridiculous. To some, this may seem sad, even like a death sentence, to be forced to make changes that we don’t want to. Unfortunately, and fortunately, we have to make sure we make changes as we age. Many women don’t change, and they continue to do the same things they always did. Big mistake because you are not the same person you were when you were twenty, thirty, or even five years ago.

Life is moving faster, even when we feel we are slowing down. Look at it like this, you were a teen once and you wore stuff you wouldn’t dream of wearing now. You naturally changed as you went into your twenties. Somewhere along the way, we stopped and got stuck. We continue to wear the same things and styles, year after year, decade after decade, without noticing that we need an update or, we do notice, but we doing nothing about it. Maybe it’s because we get caught in a time gap. Are we still young, middle age, old or what? How do we perceive ourselves at middle age? At what point or decade do we make the necessary changes that should be made for our forever changing self?

The short answer is to look back at pictures, and if you have looked the same for the last ten, fifteen, twenty years or longer, you need a serious update. Don’t panic, because it’s not hard to do. A little change in your hair style, color, makeup and clothes, and you are all set. I look at magazines for women my age, and I find inspiration through catalogs that cater to women over forty. It has served me well. In fact, I change a little too much. I change my hair color at least every six months. It’s probably not the best thing to change so often. My son was horrified when he knocked on my bedroom door the other day to ask me a question, and when I opened the door to answer him, he looked shocked and yelled out, “Mom, your hair is blue!” That statement didn’t even faze my daughter, who was sitting at the kitchen table. She didn’t even bother to look my way because she knows me so well, and this is not the first time, nor will it be the last, that I shock someone with the things I do to myself. It’s just who I am and I happen to like it. By the way, the blue color was accidental. You see I had blonde hair, and one afternoon I decided I might look better with black hair.

It was a funny mistake because the tint in the black dye turned my blonde hair blue (sounds like a country song doesn’t it?). I didn’t panic; did I mention it’s not my first time? My son, the tattletale that he is, couldn’t wait to call his dad to inform him that his wife has blue hair. My husband, being a person that doesn’t like change, and who had the lucky draw to be married to a person who does, was yet again, baffled by why I just couldn’t be like everyone else and be, in his words, “normal.” He does admit though, I keep him on his toes because he never knows who he will come home to. I rest my case! Change is a good thing.

title: The fear of aging
content:
The fear of aging

How will I handle being old? All of my life, I felt good about myself and how I looked. I definitely wasn’t a beautiful girl, but I think I got better looking as I got older. I know it’s only a matter of time before I will look in the mirror and see my old self. Who knows, I may already be there. However, I know my reflection does not define who I am. I am coming to terms with my ever-changing self.

It’s scary getting older. Maybe it’s not so much the superficial part of aging, but it’s the fear of the unknown. My body is changing, my kids have moved on, my mother is elderly, and I wonder how much longer I will be here. Will I be stricken with an illness that I cannot overcome like I could when I was younger? I know we will all die but, how will I die, I wonder.

Will my partner leave me for a younger woman? Will age discrimination show its ugly face to me? And all the while as I enjoyed being young, I told myself I would never get old. I remember, when I was a kid, I literally thought I would never get old. So many things go through my head when I think about the journey of my aging self. I suppose I could take my ego out of the situation and just let the experience happen, because fear is only part of our ego. Why not just do it, I ask myself? Yet, there is nothing I can do to stop aging as we are all going to age, and no matter how much I kick and scream, I too will have to age; and all the makeup and the creams will not stop it, no matter how much I put on.

How many times have you seen older women who are stunningly beautiful for their age? Is the key phrase here “for their age?” Why can’t we just be absolutely beautiful no matter what age we are? We see movie stars like Jane Fonda, Raquel Welch, and Sofia Loren and think, “Wow, these women are absolutely stunning; I want to look like that when I get old.” But there are two problems with this statement: The first is, they didn’t age naturally, and they had a lot of help, and I mean a lot. There’s nothing wrong with getting help, but where are all the real examples of beautifully aging women? There are some celebrities, like Diane Keaton, Michelle Pfeiffer and several others, who are beginning to balk at the need to have cosmetic surgery, and it’s refreshing to see what real aging should look like. It’s a beautiful thing that they are willing to do this in today’s culture. Sad to say though, as they get much older, they usually quietly cave-in to what society demands of women, and that is to remain youthful or just disappear.

title: Is it worth it to take medication?
content:
Is it worth it to take medication?

About two years ago, my doctor put me on thyroid medication.

Let me start from a quick beginning with out boring you to death!

I go to an OBGYN who practices natural medication as much as possible. I started going to her because I was working out pretty hard with weights and not seeing any real results. Long story short, this was the beginning of all the damn medication I'm on now!

She did a blood test and said everything looked good but my Testosterone was low. This was why I wasn't seeing results. That was about six years ago. She put me on a bio-identical cream and off I went. I gained ten pounds and gained a little muscle.

At my next check up, my Progesterone was low so I got a compound prescription and off I went again. Now I was on Testosterone and Progesterone.

Two years later after blood tests and refills, my doctor wanted to do a Boston Heart test to see where I was with my future indicators of heart disease, etc. I gave some blood and then came back for the results.

I was told that my cholesterol was high (something I never had before as I was a Vegan for 22 years) and I was shocked and saddened. This had only happened since taking the hormones more specifically, the Testosterone.

She told me to get the book Wheat Belly and adhere to it. I did and I ate not one carbohydrate or wheat for three months. When I went back to see her, she said I gained weight. I was beside myself because I was starving myself with what the book at said to do.

She said she would check my thyroid levels and sure enough she said, my thyroid was on the cusp of the normal level but descending downward for the past several years. Guess what? She put me on thyroid medicine.

I didn't trust the diagnosis so I went to a Endocrinologist and he checked my thyroid level and found nodules on my thyroid. Long story short, he said I had Hashimotos disease where my thyroid is producing antibodies that attack itself. He told me to keep taking the medication.

Wow! I asked myself if this all started because I wanted slightly bigger muscles or was I actually falling apart and they were doing what they could to keep me alive (I know a little dramatic).

Well, I was going to have a small cosmetic procedure and the doctor said "I can't do it you have heart problems" after listening to my heart. I went to a heart doctor, got some seriously long and expensive tests and turns out, I have PVC'S (premature ventricular contractions) caused by the thyroid medicine. Basically, 25% of my heart doesn't beat right because I have to take thyroid medicine.

Speed up a year or so later and I'm 48 years old. I'm sitting outside in the middle of the night, naked, on my porch from being so freaking hot, I can't stand it. Of course, my doctor puts me on Estrogen and my hot flashes end but, I get fibroids and lots of liver spots from it!

By this time, I am deficient in iron from having fibroids, deficient in a ton of other stuff too. I won't go into everything that I take but I have to wonder if all of the medication is a domino effect. I think often about stopping completely to see what my body will do.

Now, my doctor tells to get off of gluten! She said that gluten attacks the thyroid like an allergen. Well you can probably guess that I got off of gluten and now I'm on month three.

Do I feel any better? I don't think so. I have lost a few pounds and that's good. However, I know that I will go back for my blood work and then, my doctor will find one more pill to shove down my throat or a food group to take away that I have to wonder if my quality of life is worth the exchange.

title: Nothing like a good road trip to get you thinking about life...
content:
Nothing like a good road trip to get you thinking about life...

This past weekend me and the girls took a nine hour (each way) road trip to Biloxi, Mississippi.

We went to a concert, ate great food, gambled, drank champagne, shopped and had a spa day.  It was fantastic and very relaxing, just what I needed.  Needless to say, like every other weekend, it went by way too fast.

Even though the massage was out of this world and the food was amazing, it was the drive home that I enjoyed the most.

Kind of crazy that I say that because it was the long drive that I was initially dreading.  Let's face it, four women in a truck that talk too much and who want to stop and pee way to often can get a bit irritating after a couple of hours.

I have been conditioned somewhere along my life to not want to drive, to not enjoy driving and, to hurry and get there no matter what the cost!  I had no appreciation for literally, the journey along the way.

That changed when on the way back from our weekend, I don't know if the others were tired or just quietly morning the fact that we were heading back to our everyday lives but, it was silent the whole way back.

I was able to think about my life, see the sun setting, see how beautiful the trees actually were and I got to be alone with my thoughts even in the company of others.

I had many real moments where I felt waves of both sadness and happiness come over me.

I'm turning 50 in a couple of months and I'm realizing that I have to make some significant changes in my life that will make my life very uncomfortable for a while but, in the end, the changes are just what I've needed to make me happy.

Funny how we fight our thoughts and justify our lives because we go through the day to day motions, filling our spirits with being busy so that maybe, we won't have to make the decisions that are staring us in the face or whispering in our ear each day.

It's easy to go on living in a comfort zone that we're used to because being comfortable feels so good and it's warm even if, it's actually the worst thing for us.

For a very long time my spirit was dying and it was screaming for help but I just wouldn't listen to it.  I pushed the voice down and told myself to shut up and appreciate the life that I had.

Although I appreciate my life and I know others would love to have my life, I also know that right now I have choices and I don't have to be guilty about wanting to be happy.  The biggest epiphany that I had was realizing that I can't make others happy.  I can only make myself.  Something I have not done in about ten years.

I've always felt responsible for making others happy but I didn't realize that until I took my road trip.  The cost was more that the money I had left at the casino and I decided I wasn't going to pay for the rest of my life.

If you don't get anything else from this blog post, please know and take that statement to heart.  "You can't make others happy." And, you are not responsible for making others happy either.  All you can do is be kind and be yourself.

Sometimes all you need is a good road trip to get you thinking about life!

title: What we think is truly who we are..
content:
For the last several months, I've been going through some personal issues.  While I won't burden others with what they are, I will say that the way I feel physically and mentally has been like being on a roller coaster!

One day I'm hopeful and the next, I'm planning a future that I'm terrified of. Only to bounce back and forth for what seems like a time in my life that will be a long road of uncertainty.

I've come to realize that, what ever the long term decision I make, I won't make it too quick and if that means to others that I'm sitting on the fence, then I'll sit on the fence for just a bit longer.

I have always believed that while going through rough times, we can either wallow in the pain and ask why me (and believe me I know that grieving any type of loss is normal and should happen) there are moments that creep into my mind that ask another question and that is "now what are you going to do about it?"

Which brings me to the whole point of this blog post.  Why do I let my mind tell me how or direct how, I feel each day?

When times are good I feel great and the sadness and worry no longer enter my mind but, when things take a turn for the worse, all of the fear and the "what if" takes over my mind and my spirit, leaving me metaphorically dragging until the next wave of hope comes along.

Then, I am happy again and the world is mine.  What happens when that next happy wave doesn't come?  Will I slither into a dark hole that I can't get out of?  If so then why?  Why would I let myself do that when nothing externally has changed?  People change around me but I don't and I'm realizing that this is the root cause of my pain.  I don't have to or wan't to be anything but who I am.

When I am happy nothing outside me has changed just my thoughts.  When I'm down nothing outside me has changed either, just my thoughts again.

I have come to realize that circumstances shouldn't dictate how I feel and how I see the world.  Controlling ones mind is not that difficult if we stop the intruding thoughts that we ourselves create.  We create bad thoughts, we create good thoughts, it's just the same. It's what we attach to those thoughts that is the issue.

I remember this past week driving in my Jeep (which I love to do) with the windows down, the radio blasting and feeling the cool breeze at the moment and then the next moment breaking down crying while singing along with the song on the radio.  Only then, to smile again with happiness that things aren't so bad ( by now you're probably thinking I need professional help but keep reading).

At that moment I made a commitment to myself and that was to keep that pleasant thought in my mind of being in the moment and knowing that I myself control how I feel and how I will feel from then on no matter what circumstances bring me.  I have the power, I always have and I always will..

The statement "change your thoughts, change your life" couldn't be more true :)

title: Welcome to My Aging and Wellness...
content:
Hello everyone.

Today is the new beginning of this blog! I say new because it’s been hacked and shut down twice!  I won’t go into why but I will say it’s because I let others have control and today I decided to make a new start with me being the one in control.  Kind of like the epiphany of my life.

This blog and website is about aging well.  I’m not talking about being twenty again or doing things to your body that are counter intuitive to aging and being well but, what I will write about what I’m passionate about and that is aging well and living a passionate life.

At times, I will talk about things that may seem a little vain because hell, I’m trying like everyone else to make the transition into aging and accepting it.

Even though aging is not very easy on the body and in a world full of marketers that have forgotten about us middle age and older people, there is a place within our spirit that we can carve out and make aging a place in time where we can feel good, both mentally and physically.

Do I want to live to be 100!  I don’t know.  Maybe I do if I look okay and my body doesn’t break down.  I do know one thing for certain and that is that I don’t want to be depending on someone, especially my kids to take care of me so, my writing here will be about all of the things that we deal with while getting older and how to take care of our mind, body and spirit, the best that we can without being too rigid in the process.

We have to live and I won’t stop drinking my wine no matter what my doctor or anyone else says!  Those who know me also know this about me too.  That’s the thing.  There comes a certain point and time in our lives that we become who WE want to be and with the courage, WE actually live the kind of life that WE want to and not what other expect us to.

At this point in life, I don’t want to tell others how to live and I sure as hell don’t want them to tell me how to live my life because frankly, I really don’t care.  Those times are behind me and I won’t look back because, I’m not going that way anymore.

I hope to bring you inspiration, reference, ideas, laughs and, videos of those who are living and aging well and topics that are helpful.

I will leave you with something:

“Enjoy your body, Use it every way you can... Don't be afraid of it, or what other people Think of it.

It's the greatest instrument you'll ever own...”

~Baz Luhrmann
